Core Terms

transferred, parties, user
Case Summary
Overview
Virtual world participants brought a contract and tort 
action against the virtual world operators, alleging that 
their virtual property was unlawfully confiscated. The 
operators sought dismissal and/or transfer of the matter 
to California under 28 U.S.C.S. § 1404(a). The court 
found that as California's venue affidavit requirement in 
Cal. Civ. Code § 1780(d) was a procedural rule, 
dismissal was not warranted. A mandatory forum 
selection clause in the operators' terms of service 
applied and was not unfair, unconscionable, or 
unreasonable under California law.
Outcome
Dismissal granted in part; action transferred.

To bring an action under the California Consumer Legal

]  Federal & State Interrelationships, Erie 
Doctrine
Whether a state rule is substantive or procedural 
involves a two-step analysis. First, a court must 
determine whether the state rule is in direct conflict with 
a Federal Rule of Civil Procedure. If so, the Federal 
Rule prevails. However, if there is no direct conflict, the 
court considers the "twin aims" of the Erie doctrine: 
discouragement of forum shopping and avoidance of 
inequitable administration of the laws. The Supreme 
Court has added two qualifications to the Erie analysis. 
First, a strong federal interest may dictate the 
application of the federal rule. Second, the Erie doctrine 
cannot be used to avoid a Federal Rule of Civil 
Procedure.

]  Defenses, Unconscionability
Under California law, terms of a contract can be 
procedurally and/or substantively unconscionable. The 
procedural component can be satisfied by showing: (1) 
oppression through the existence of unequal bargaining

in the context of adhesion contracts. The substantive

one-sided results that "shock the conscience." The two 
elements operate on a sliding scale such that the more 
significant one is, the less significant the other need be.

Here, the forum selection clause does not seem to meet 
the test of unconscionable or unreasonable under 
California law. When a person signs up for a Second 
Life account or logs into an existing account  [**13] after 
Defendants' TOS has been changed, a dialogue box is 
displayed to the user with the full text of the most 
current TOS. The user must affirmatively consent to the

access their account. Users who do not click "I Agree" 
are not allowed to continue in the login process to 
Second Life. (Rountree Decl. ¶3.)
The second paragraph of the TOS reads, "By using 
Second Life, you agree to and accept these Terms of 
Service. If you do not so agree, you should decline this

accessing or using Second Life." (Linden Lab's March 
31, 2010 Terms of Service ("TOS") ¶2, Def.'s Mot. to 
Dismiss Ex. 1 at 15 ("Def. Ex.").) There is also a forum 
selection clause which reads:
You agree that this Agreement and the relationship 
between you and Linden Lab shall be governed by 
the laws of the State of California . . . . Further, you 
and Linden Lab agree to submit to the exclusive 
jurisdiction and venue of the courts located in the 
City and County of San Francisco, California, 
except as provided in Section 12.1 regarding 
optional arbitration.
(TOS § 12.2, Def. Ex. 1:B-2 at 2.) Thus, it is clear that

 [**16] agreed upon by the parties." (TOS § 12.1, Def. 
Ex. 1:B-2 at 2.) In light of these circumstances, 6 the 
forum selection clause  [*742]  of Linden's new TOS is 
not unfair or unconscionable.
Finally, to determine whether Linden's current TOS 
applied to each Plaintiff, the parties were asked to 
provide supplemental briefing regarding each account 
held by the Plaintiffs and which TOS each account had 
agreed too. The information provided shows that each 
Plaintiff agreed to the March, 2010 TOS at some point 
before this action was brought. Thus, the forum 
selection clause requiring that any  [**17] cases brought 
against the Defendant be brought in the Northern 
District of California is enforceable as to all Plaintiffs in 
this case.
IV. CONCLUSION
For the reasons stated above, Defendants' Motion to 
Dismiss is granted in part and denied in part. The 
5 Linden also retains the option to demand arbitration of claims 
under $10,000.
6 If the claimant decides to proceed in Court, under the new 
TOS, California law will apply and the litigation must be 
brought in San Francisco. Given that Linden operates 
nationwide, Linden has a legitimate business interest in 
uniform application of the law and in centralizing litigation in 
one location. This dual purpose is served by an agreement 
that California law applies and that the litigation of claims over 
$10,000 take place in San Francisco. Moreover, the selection 
of California law is reasonable, given that Linden is located in 
California and that California law is in many ways a consumer-
friendly forum.
motion is granted in part as the forum selection clause 
will be enforced as to all Plaintiffs. However, the motion 
is denied in part as the case will not be dismissed but 
instead will be transferred to the Northern District of 
California pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 1406. An appropriate 
order will follow.
ORDER
AND NOW, this 3rd day of February, 2011 for the 
reasons set forth in the Court's accompanying 
memorandum dated February 3, 2011, it is ORDERED 
that:
1. Defendants' Motion to Dismiss (doc. no. 11) is 
GRANTED in part and DENIED in part. Defendants' 
motion will be granted as the Court finds that the forum 
selection clause applies so that the case cannot be 
pursued in this Court. Defendants' motion is denied in 
part as the case will not be dismissed but transferred to 
the United States District Court for the Northern District 
of California.
2. The Clerk of the Court shall TRANSFER the case to 
the United States District Court for the Northern 
 [**18] District of California.
3. Defendants' motions for leave to file replies (doc. nos. 
16 & 26) are GRANTED.
4. Plaintiffs' Motion for Leave to File a Second Amended 
Complaint (doc. no. 13) will be DENIED as moot.
AND IT IS SO ORDERED.
/s/ Eduardo C. Robreno
EDUARDO C. ROBRENO, J.

## Summary

- Case Summary: 

### Case Identification

- Judge(s) presiding: Eduardo C. Robreno

- Decision date: February 3, 2011

### Parties and Representatives

- Plaintiff(s) and their attorneys: Not specified
- Defendant(s) and their attorneys: Not specified

### Legal Issues

- Questions the court needs to resolve: Enforceability of mandatory forum selection clause and arbitration clause in Second Life's Terms of Service

### Procedural History

- Journey through the legal system: The case was brought in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania, and the court granted in part and denied in part the defendant's motion to dismiss.
- Previous court decisions and appeals: Not specified

F1.content: Evans v. Linden Research, Inc. is a contract and tort action filed by Carl Evans, Donald Spencer, Valerie Spencer, and Cindy Carter against Linden Research, Inc. and Philip Rosedale.

F2.content: The case involves a virtual world and the confiscation of virtual property.

F3.content: The California Consumer Legal Remedies Act (CLRA) requires plaintiffs to file a venue affidavit concurrently with the filing of the complaint.

F5.content: A mandatory forum selection clause in the defendants' terms of service applies and is not unfair, unconscionable, or unreasonable under California law.

F8.content: The defendants are seeking dismissal of the action and/or transfer of the case to California.

F9.content: Second Life is a virtual world where participants create avatars and engage in various activities, including buying and selling virtual goods.

F10.content: Linden Research, Inc. is the operator of Second Life.

F11.content: Plaintiffs were participants in Second Life and alleged that Linden Research, Inc. and Philip Rosedale had unlawfully confiscated their virtual property and denied them access to their virtual worlds.

F12.content: Plaintiffs brought their complaint to the court on April 15, 2010, and their amended complaint on June 16, 2010.

F16.content: The arbitration clause in the TOS gives the claimant the option to proceed to arbitration and have the claim heard by telephone, on-line, or by written submission, without having to appear in San Francisco.

F17.content: The court is comparing the arbitration clause in the TOS to the arbitration clause in Bragg, which was found to be unconscionable.

L1.content: California's venue affidavit requirement is a procedural rule under Erie and as such, the Plaintiff in this case is not required to follow it.
L1.source: Evans v. Linden Research, Inc., 763 F. Supp. 2d 735

L3.content: A forum selection clause may be unenforceable where it is found to be unconscionable.

L4.content: Under California law, terms of a contract can be procedurally and/or substantively unconscionable.

L5.content: California courts have specifically addressed the issue of enforcing mandatory forum selection clauses.

L7.content: The court must determine whether the state rule is in direct conflict with a Federal Rule of Civil Procedure.

L8.content: The Erie doctrine considers the 'twin aims' of the doctrine: to avoid the inconvenience of applying state law and to ensure that federal courts do not apply state law in a way that is inconsistent with federal law.
L8.source: Gasperini v. Center for Humanities, Inc., 518 U.S. 415, 116 S. Ct. 2211, 135 L. Ed. 2d 659 (1996)

L9.content: A strong federal interest may dictate the application of the federal rule, and the Erie doctrine cannot be used to avoid a Federal Rule of Civil Procedure.
L9.source: Chamberlain v. Giampapa, 210 F.3d 154, 159 (3d Cir. 2000) citing Byrd v. Blue Ridge Rural Electric Coop., Inc., 356 U.S. 525, 538, 78 S. Ct. 893, 2 L. Ed. 2d 953 (1958); Hanna, 380 U.S. at 470.

L10.content: Even if an agreement is procedurally unconscionable, it may nonetheless be enforceable if the substantive terms are reasonable.

L11.content: Substantive unconscionability focuses on the one-sideness of the contract terms.

L12.content: Although not even a 'mandatory' forum selection clause can completely eliminate a court's discretion to make appropriate rulings regarding choice of forum, the modern trend is to enforce mandatory forum selection clauses unless they are unfair or unreasonable.
L12.source: Olinick v. BMG Entertainment, 138 Cal. App. 4th 1286, 42 Cal. Rptr. 3d 268, 274 (Cal. Ct. App. 2006)

L13.content: If there is a mandatory forum selection clause, the test is simply whether application of the clause is unfair or unreasonable, and the clause is usually given effect.
L13.source: Olinick v. BMG Entertainment, 138 Cal. App. 4th 1286, 42 Cal. Rptr. 3d 268, 274 (Cal. Ct. App. 2006)

L14.content: Claims that the previously chosen forum is unfair or inconvenient are generally rejected.
L14.source: Olinick v. BMG Entertainment, 138 Cal. App. 4th 1286, 42 Cal. Rptr. 3d 268, 274 (Cal. Ct. App. 2006)

L15.content: A court will usually honor a mandatory forum selection clause without extensive analysis of factors relating to convenience because '[m]ere inconvenience or additional expense is not the test of unreasonableness of a mandatory forum selection clause.'
L15.source: Olinick v. BMG Entertainment, 138 Cal. App. 4th 1286, 42 Cal. Rptr. 3d 268, 274 (Cal. Ct. App. 2006)

D1.content: The court found that California's venue affidavit requirement in Cal. Civ. Code § 1780(d) is a procedural rule, and dismissal was not warranted. A mandatory forum selection clause in the operators' terms of service applied and was not unfair, unconscionable, or unreasonable under California law.

D2.content: The court granted dismissal in part and transferred the action to California under 28 U.S.C.S. § 1404(a).

D3.content: The court finds that the mandatory forum selection clause included in the defendants' current Terms of Service applies. The court grants the defendants' Motion to Dismiss in part and denies it in part, and the case will be transferred to the Northern District of California.

D4.content: The court determines that the venue affidavit requirement is a procedural rule and does not have a significant impact on the outcome of the case. The court denies the defendants' Motion to Dismiss Count I of the plaintiffs' complaint.

D5.content: The court finds that the forum selection clause is not substantively unconscionable and is enforceable. The court denies the plaintiffs' motion to show that the forum selection clause is unconscionable.

D6.content: The court ruled that the forum selection clause in the Terms of Service (TOS) is enforceable and will be applied to all plaintiffs, transferring the case to the Northern District of California.

D7.content: The court found that the arbitration clause in the TOS is not unfair or unconscionable, giving the claimant the option to proceed to arbitration for claims under $10,000.

D8.content: The court denied the motion to dismiss the case, but granted the motion to transfer the case to the Northern District of California.
